descript.abstract: Observations from the moderate resolution imaging spectroradiometer (MODIS) were used in combination with a large data set of Field measurements to map woody above-ground biomass (AGB) across tropical Africa. We generated a best-quality cloud-free mosaic of MODIS satellite reflectance observations for the period 2000-2003 and used a regression tree model to predict AGB at 1 km resolution. Results based on a cross-validation approach show that the model explained 82% of the variance in AGB, with a root mean square error of 50.5 Mg ha-1 for a range of biomass between 0 and 454 Mg ha-1 . Analysis of lidar metrics from the Geoscience Laser Altimetry System (GLAS), which are sensitive to vegetation structure, indicate that the model successfully captured the regional distribution of AGB. The results showed a strong positive correlation ( R2 = 0.90) between the GLAS height metrics and predicted AGB.
descript.purpose: The United Nations Framework Convention in Climate Change (UNFCCC) recognized the important role of deforestation in the carbon cycle, particularly in tropical forestes ecosystems. This map is a step towards developing baseline estimates of Above-ground biomass for carbon-credit allocation schemes to reduce emissions from deforestation and forest degradation (REDD) in in tropical Africa. This represents satellite-derived baseline estimates of above-ground biomass for the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
